body.p: Liquid Site uses a specific terminology that is important to understand in order to administrate a web site. These same terms are also used extensively in this reference manual and in other documents. The list below attempts to define and describe the most important of these terms.

item.title: CSS
item.text: The Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) format is the most common layout and styling langugage used on the world wide web. The CSS format is text-based and readable by both humans and machines. A CSS file contains detailed layout and formatting instructions for HTML documents, allowing a single style sheet to be used for several documents. A working knowledge of CSS is required in order to modify the layout of web pages.

item.title: HTML
item.text: The HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the most common document format used on the world wide web. The HTML format is text-based and readable by both humans and machines. An HTML document normally only contains the text and overall structure of a web page, using external CSS style sheets and image files for specifying the layout. A working knowledge of HTML is required in order to modify the layout of web pages.

item.title: Page
item.text: A web page contains HTML code presenting the web content. The HTML code for each page is split into one or more Page Elements allowing individual elements to be reused across different pages. Pages can inherit the page elements from other pages, typically Template pages.

item.title: Page Element
item.text: A page element is a piece of HTML code for a part of a document. A page element may also contain references to other page elements, thereby creating an element hierarchy. Such a page element hierarchy can be inherited between Pages, allowing overriding a single page element in the hierarchy. A page element is identified by it's name.

item.title: Site
item.text: A web site consists of a collection of documents and files available from a single location on the world wide web. A web site is normally identified by a host name, for example www.liquidsite.org. It is also possible to share a single host name and separate the sites by their base directory. Web sites can only share information with other sites in the same Site Group, but they can of course link to public resources on other sites.

item.title: Site Group
item.text: A site group is a set of Sites that share common resources. Users and Groups are always shared between the sites in a site group. Files, templates, and pages may be shared by using Aliases.

item.title: Template
item.text: A template is a Page that is only used as a parent for other pages. A template page consists of Page Elements with HTML code just as normal pages. Templates can inherit the page elements from other templates, creating a hierarchy of more refined templates.
